INVESTIGATION:
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of Staff: The licensee shall have a
Section sufficient number of administrative, supervisory, social service, direct
Description care, and other staff on duty to perform the prescribed functions
required by these administrative rules and in the agency’s program
statement and to provide for the continual needs, protection, and
supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Between 11/12/22 and 11/27/22, youth raped another youth at the
facility by forcing youth to perform oral sex. This occurred while in
quarantine.
Investigation On 12/21/2022 the special investigation was initiated on site at
Clarence Fischer Center (CFC). An in-person interview was held with
the Program Manager (PM). She was advised of the allegations and
confirmed that Youth B was no longer placed at the facility. She also
confirmed that Youth A remained and was at the facility today. PM
2

advised that during the two-week time frame that was provided as an
alleged time when the incident occurred, both Youth A and Youth B
were in quarantine together due to COVID 19 exposure. Per PM the
youth were in quarantine together from 11/12/22 to 11/27/22. PM
explained that during waking hours all exposed youth remained in the
quarantine unit and during sleeping hours all youth are relocated to one
unit and separated in the different areas of the unit. I completed a walk
through of the area and found there to be adequate space and distance
in the area to allow for continued isolation of the exposed youth. PM
advised that all youth were combined together in one area around 8-
9pm. Per PM, during the afternoon shift they were always staffed with
two youth care workers. PM reported that during the alleged timeframe
of 11/12/22 to 11/27/22 Staff 1 and Staff 2 were staffed on Tuesday and
Wednesday for the afternoon shift. PM reported that Youth A reported
the allegations to Staff 1 on the morning of 12/20/22. Youth A reported
that it occurred on second shift on a Tuesday or Wednesday and that
Staff 2 was the only staff present. PM reported that the agency was
fully staffed during that time and both Staff 1 and Staff 2 were on shift.
On 12/21/2022 an interview was completed with the complainant.
There were no additional concerns reported.
On 12/21/2022 an in-person meeting was held with Youth A. Youth A
took me on a tour of the unit that was being utilized as the quarantine
unit in November 2022. He confirmed that he was comfortable at the
facility and currently feels safe. An interview of Youth A was not
completed at that time as it had not been confirmed if law enforcement
clearance had been provided.
On 01/12/2023 an in-person interview was completed with Youth A at
CFC. Youth A reported that he was “raped” by Youth B and was not
able to yell for help. He also reported that Youth B threatened him and
stated he would “beat his ass” if he yelled. Youth A defined rape as
making “me suck his penis”. He further reported that only he and Youth
B were in the rear of the unit because they were in quarantine. Youth A
reported that only Staff B was in the unit with them and reported he was
not sitting in a position where he could see them. When asked if he
recalled seeing the staff walk around and monitor, he replied he could
not remember. he saw staff Youth A reported that the incident occurred
during second shift at about 9 or 9:30 pm. Youth A then reported that
he told staff, but no one really listened. He was unable to recall who or
when he told the staff and specifically indicated “I forgot”. Youth A
denied that it had happened before and reported that it had not
happened again.
4

On 01/21/2023 an in-person interview was completed with Staff 1 at
CFC. Staff 1 reported that she is a youth care worker and has been
employed with the agency since July 2022. She reported that she
works second shift (2pm to 10pm) every Sunday -Thursday. Staff 1
reported that she was sitting at the staff table in Unit 2 alone and Youth
A asked if she could tell her something. She responded yes and stated
that Youth A stated that Youth B raped him. Staff 1 stated that she did
not go into detail with him, but immediately reported it to PM and
Residential Care Supervisor (RCS). She confirmed that she was
working during the quarantine days between 11/12/22 and 11/27/22.
Staff 1 reported that she specifically monitored Youth A and Youth B
and does not ever recall seeing any inappropriate exchange between
the two. She also reported that she recalled that Youth B was very
“grossed out” by a medical condition that Youth A had which required
him to wear a diaper and have frequent cleanings and changes by staff,
and as a result he would not engage with him. She denied that there
was a time that both her and Staff 2 were providing supervision of the
youth. She further denied that any other youth have expressed
concerns regarding inappropriate behavior involving Youth A or Youth
B. Staff 1 reported that Youth B has a history with aggressive behavior
toward staff, but not other youth in the facility. Lastly, Staff 1 denied
there was a time that she is aware of that the facility was out of ratio
compliance.
On 01/12/2023 in-person interviews were held with Youth C, Youth D
and Youth E at CFC. They all denied hearing or seeing Youth A or
Youth B engage inappropriate behavior with other youth. They all also
reported that they were not in the quarantine unit, but have shared a
unit with Youth A or Youth B after 11/27/22. They all denied that there
were times that they were aware of the agency not being in compliance
with staffing ratio.
On 02/08/2023 a phone interview was completed with Staff 2. It should
be noted that Staff 2 is no longer employed by the agency. Staff 2
confirmed that he was previously employed by the agency and worked
2nd shift which was from 2pm to 10pm. He recalled that when he
returned to work around 12/20/22 or 12/21/22, he was asked some
questions about the monitoring of Youth A and Youth B because Youth
A had made some allegations about inappropriate behavior by Youth B.
Staff 2 recalled that the agency had experienced a COVID-19 outbreak
and had some youth that were in quarantine due to exposure. He
confirmed that Youth A and Youth B were being housed in the rear of
the unit after “fall in time” which he defined as after 8pm. He reported
that both he and Staff 1 would be in the unit with the youth and Staff 1
was primarily assigned to monitor Youth A and Youth B to ensure they
were following isolation protocol. He reported that when both were
4

present, he monitored the front and Staff 1 monitored the back. Staff 2
reported that Staff 1 ended her shift at 8pm and when she would leave
for the night, he would walk from the front and back to thoroughly
monitor the youth. He reported that he would stand and sit mostly in
the middle for the best monitoring, especially after the cameras were
turned off. Staff 2 also reported that he took pictures of all of his
documentation because he wanted to make sure he had copies of what
he was reporting. Staff 2 denied seeing any inappropriate contact
between any youth and specifically between Youth A and Youth B. He
also denied that there was ever a time that he was not monitoring
behavior of the youth. He confirmed that the youth would be down (or
in bed) for the night by 8pm. Staff 2 denied that he was advised by
Youth A of any inappropriate behavior that happened to him while
placed at CFC.
On 02/09/2023 a video interview was completed with Youth B. He
confirmed that he was previously placed at CFC and recalled being in
quarantine with Youth A. He could not recall the specific dates he was
in quarantine, but stated it was after Halloween and before Christmas.
He recalled that only he and Youth A were in quarantine together. He
reported that during the day they were in one unit, but at night they
went next door to another unit and sleep in the back of the unit. He
reported that they had to sleep in the back to quarantine because they
had been exposed to COVID-19. Youth B reported that staff would be
in the area supervising them and would not leave unless another staff
came to give them a break. He reported that the staff would be in the
front and the back of the unit. Youth B denied that there was any time
that staff was not present in the unit. He also denied that he and Youth
A engaged in any type of inappropriate activity.
The following documents were reviewed as a part of the investigation:
• Face sheets for all youth interviewed: Face sheets include
identifying information for each youth
• Incident Report: Documented report of Youth A to Staff 1 of
inappropriate sexual contact by Youth B. Incident report also
indicates that Youth A reported that only Staff 2 was present
during the incident.
• Written statement submitted by Youth A: The written account
of what Youth A reported.
• Unit Shift Log Entries from 11/12/22 to 11/27/22
• SST Shift Log Entries from 11/12/22 to 11/27/22
• Staff schedule for afternoon shift for CFC from 11/12/22 to
11/27/22 Confirms schedule of both Staff 1 and Staff 2. Also
confirms that Staff 1 worked beyond 8pm
4

Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation there was not sufficient evidence
to support non-compliance of licensing Rule 400.4126 via a lack of
supervision of youth by CFC staff. Two staff and one youth that were
interviewed all deny that there was a time that staff was not properly
supervising youth in the unit. There is a discrepancy between the
reports of Youth A and Youth B regarding inappropriate contact
between the youth, however there is no evidence to support that any
inappropriate contact that occurred was a result of lack of supervision
by the staff.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was provided with technical assistance regarding licensing
rule R400.4127(4). In order to accommodate for the proper quarantine
of youth that had been exposed to COVID-19, an alternative sleeping
arrangement was developed. Staff typically set in the room with youth
while they are sleeping, however, the alternative sleeping arrangement
caused Youth A and Youth B to be outside of the direct line of sight of
staff. Although no one reported lack of supervising, there is not proper
documentation to show that checks during sleeping hours were
completed at varying intervals not exceeding 15 minutes.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract and policy.
It is recommended that the current license status be continued.
